notesStmt.note: Whitman quotes this passage, with minor variations, from George Sand, The Countess of Rudolstadt, trans. Francis G. Shaw (2 vols., New York, 1848). This novel was the sequel to George Sand's Consuelo, accounting in part for Whitman's citation; his copies of both novels, held by the Library of Congress Rare Books division, are now disbound, but the 1858 catalog of the New York Mercantile Library (p. 37) lists the two novels bound together in its collection at the time.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: ["The unknown refused to explain]
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original item.

body.p: "The unknown refused to explain himself. 'What could I say to you that I have not said in another (my own) language? Is it my fault that you have not understood me? You think I wished to speak to your senses, & it was my soul spoke to you. What do I say! It was the soul of the whole of humanity that spoke to you through mine'."—George Sand.
